chapter.title: Building Kernel Modules
chapter.para: The standard method for building and distributing kernel modules on openSUSE and SUSE Linux Enterprise is by creating Kernel Module Packages (KMPs). KMPs are RPM packages specifically designed to handle kernel modules.

The main advantage of using KMPs is that they are built to work against multiple kernel flavors (like default, desktop, or xen) and are managed correctly by the package manager during kernel updates, ensuring the module remains available for the newly installed kernel.

section.title: The KMP Spec File
section.para: The core of a KMP is the RPM .spec file. The process is heavily simplified by using the %kernel_module_package macro, which is provided by the kmp-macros package. This macro automatically creates the necessary sub-packages for each kernel flavor your project is configured to build against.

listitem.para: Add BuildRequires: kmp-macros to pull in the required macro.
Add BuildRequires: kernel-devel to build against the kernel sources.
Call the %kernel_module_package macro in the preamble of your spec file.

example.title: Example KMP .spec Preamble
example.programlisting:
Name: my-driver Version: 1.0 Release: 1 Summary: My kernel module License: GPL-2.0-only
# Add the required BuildRequires BuildRequires: kmp-macros BuildRequires: kernel-devel BuildRequires: modutils
# Call the KMP macro %kernel_module_package
%description This package contains the kernel module for my-driver.
%prep # ... (rest of your spec file)

section.para: The KMP macros automatically handle installing the module into the correct directory, typically /lib/modules/VERSION-RELEASE-FLAVOR/updates/. You should not manually place files in kernel directories.
